Content: The global market for collaborative robots, or cobots, is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 41.8 per cent until 2026, according to research by MarketsandMarkets. The answer to the rise of the cobots is its development and launch of new product ranges, such as the JMHZ series of grippers and JSY series of valve blocks. Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For ‚Äúgreenfield‚Äù products, ROS has a future.  Niche products like AGV/AMR stand a lot to gain by leveraging the platform.  As far as becoming a core part of a production process, the adoption of ROS will be complicated.  The robot hardware itself will be a major factor.  Most industrial ROS applications I‚Äôm aware of have been with a ‚Äúbrownfield‚Äù approach.  That is, ROS functions as a supervisor or management shell for a commercially available industrial robot.

ROS adoption in industry is still extremely low.  Many of the integrators and personnel in the robot industry aren't aware of the technology.  I believe a major factor is that largest consumers of robots deploy them for high-volume production and, hence, don't perceive the benefits of the technology.  They started using robots precisely because they did not have to be flexible.  Think material handling, assembly, welding, or painting for dedicated production lines.  Because these firms have already invested in the infrastructure, the marginal cost of continuing to use it on new deployments or maintaining existing ones is very low.  They would have to be utilizing robotics in a different way or with a different mindset to realize the benefits of ROS.

Another factor is the "industrial worthiness".  Fanuc, for example, has a very robust network of support.  It's easy to obtain parts, talent, training, etc.  The second-hand, refurbished market is incredible.  It's very evolutionary technology and extremely dependable.  Even if one is still using proven Fanuc hardware they're familiar with, it's a massive leap-of-faith putting a new third-party supervisor on top of it.  They don't have many resources to lean on for support if they run into issues.  Anecdotally, I can find more people across three continents that know the Fanuc SDK ("KAREL") than ROS.  I don't believe this is a coincidence.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here is an analogy.  Imagine replacing a turn-key DCS with open-source software while keeping the original hardware.  Even if the software is unequivocally better and should theoretically work, it is not an easy undertaking.  One must commit resources to manage the risks.  The assets can‚Äôt run without the DCS.  Most organizations are not setup to tolerate the short-term pain and work out bugs on-the-fly.  They will resort to a conservative posture.  I think of ROS as this on a much smaller scale.  It‚Äôs marrying a robot hardware to a new frontier of software.  It takes brains and courage to pull this off.

Where ROS is optimal is lower-volume, high-mix production.  The intelligence of ROS can make robot assets much more flexible and agile.  It can help enable a manufacturer to have scale and scope.  Solving the scale-scope dichotomy is one the major objectives of Industrie 4.0.  The challenge with lower-volume manufacturers is that they adopt automation much more conservatively.  It requires much more creativity achieving ROI.  They‚Äôre not trying to streamline a few processes that will cycle millions of times.  They have to make that investment work on a variety of processes.  Their problem space is much complicated.

The other key area where ROS could benefit is in vision.  Industrial robots are still somewhat primitive motion control systems.  It‚Äôs hard for them to intelligently interface with vision sensors.  A lot of context is missed between the vision and robotic nodes.  Additionally, there are all sorts of interoperability issues.  ROS could be an intelligent, less-proprietary domain to contextually bridge these nodes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, it‚Äôs incredible. I was blown away the first time I saw it.

As to whether it can work with SpB, I think it comes down to the information modeling. I suppose it‚Äôs all theoretically possible. SpB, in most implementations, strikes me somewhat as a continuous data stream or exchange of I/O for SCADA applications rather than a service that is invoked. It‚Äôs not like a ‚Äúconversational‚Äù REST API. Logic must be introduced on both ends to constrain meaning and interpretation. That's not to say this is bad. SpB could have been conceived for more practical adoption instead of "boiling the ocean" with advanced features. It seems like a lot of the focus is on data acquisition as opposed to control. I can‚Äôt fault this as there is a ton of pent-up value here -- particular in brownfield contexts. There's enough of a harvest to eat for years. Beyond this, I think there is a lot potential for enhancing the payloads for more intelligent supervisory control. Industrie 4.0 is not just about obtaining greater visibility, but also producing more flexibly.

In this demo, they‚Äôre making use of the methods facet. It exposes what the device can do, can receive commands, confirm, etc. It‚Äôs a full semantic handshake.

The really unfortunate part about this demo is there is nothing available on how to recreate it. I don‚Äôt even know that you could go to Kuka, Beckhoff, SAP, etc and place an order to enable something like this. This is why I think adoption is bigger problem than some of the technical critiques (e.g., heaviness, verbosity, openness). Outside of a booth at Hannover Messe or SPS IPC Drives, it‚Äôs relatively impractical to do this in the real-world.

Author: akoscs
Content: Hi, I have industrial robot programming experience and even wrote my own parser, based on some of the ANTLR grammars published. I have encountered many obstacles until I implemented 2 interpreters for 2 different languages (including simulating the underlying robot behavior). The syntax was never the problem. I was always happy with the syntax definitions I found in the manuals. The problem was always the default values of some of the system variables, which are needed not necessarily for the interpreter, but to actually simulate the robot behavior based on a program. Furthermore, exactly replicating path/trajectory planning is not possible. You can come close, but it never will be exact.

Author: akoscs
Content: The interpreter is just the first step in this regard. It just transforms the program into a more manageable data structure (in the case of ANTLR an AST Tree) and offers an easy to use way to enable attaching logic to different elements in the AST. That is far from the robot behavior. The hard part comes after that, when you want to simulate the robot behavior described in the program. To do that exactly is not possible, since there is no in depth information available about the path/trajectory planning, dynamic models and closed loop control of the robot, You can get close with a considerable amount of work, but it never will be exact.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: There are many different strategies I have seen integrators and myself interface between PLC and robot controllers.  My favourite is to treat the robot as a dumb device and let the PLC call the shots. Too many architect the robot controller as the central piece. All of those integrations have been a huge pain in the behind for the end user. Let the PLC issue commands and have the robot echo back. Break up robot program into logical sequences that the PLC orchestrate. Rarely have to pick up a pendant to recover components failures or sensor faults.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
@shreyas state machines are commonly used in PLCs to sequence and control a process. Case statements with persistent states, allowing for recovery from any situation (important for robotics - as you might fail mid process, and can not just back out of what the robot is currently doing). The PLC manages the states, and as @jpmoniz says, handshake processes, and if sharing a space, exchange tokens for ownership. 

You can do this over tcp with the FANUC LR mate (or equivalent) controller. No teach pendant is fine, but i encourage you to pick one up and get the feel of a robot using it.....you'll likely have to rely on one, and they are quite sophisticated comparatively these days.

Author: rhuisken
Content:
I started as a robot programmer before learning PLC's, specifically Yaskawa robots. I utilized the ladder-like aspect of the robot controller, and user programmable buttons on the pendant as an HMI. Where it eventually failed and why I now advocate for a proper PLC + HMI:
- Code inside the robot was hard to maintain. Everything is numerical addresses. Sure, there are areas where those addresses can be named, but not all. And those names are not displayed when you're in the ladder editing environment.
- You're more limited on what you can display to the user on the robot pendant. An HMI can be powerful for displaying the right information at the right time. Adding intelligence to a robot- giving it the ability to make decisions- is only effective if that can be communicated to and understood by the user.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
@RobH I would normally advocate for the same, but i also started as a robot programmer and i deployed a nachi robot with a teach pendant HMI that went to production for 5 years. The addresses were named and the soft plc IO were used for real time force control integration (parallel thread). I have done similar with Denso and Kuka. 

I think PLCs are amazing, and in most cases needed, but modern robot controllers have PLCs built in, extendable IO, and GUIs as well....just bares repeating. Although, i dont disagree, robot HMIs dont compare to a PLCs

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's easy to love and hate Fanuc.  On one hand, you always know what you're getting.  It has it's quirks and learning curve, but it's remarkably consistent.  On the other hand, it's like they never really got over their "divorce" with GE and are stuck in the past.  It feels, from interfacing and manageability perspective, like ancient technology.  There's no one engineering or development environment.  All the functionality is spread across different PC apps, teach pendent menus, packages/options, manuals, etc.  My biggest gripe is that they have no true self-serve resources to discover capabilities.  It always requires calling someone or ordering some obscure printed manual or CD-ROM.  But, their support is generally very knowledgable.   When one considers all the ways its been deployed, it's really resilient technology.  Additionally, the second-hand/refurb market and MRO availability is incredible.  It's also not hard to find talent familiar with it.  It's really a lesson that it's not always the "best" technology wins.

My favorite quirk is their HMI on the teach pendents.  It's HTML-based with ActiveX objects.  So, their prescribed way of managing the interface is with... Microsoft Frontpage.  The last release of Frontpage was in 2003.  They ship millions of dollars of robots each year with manuals guiding their customers through Microsoft Frontpage.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Excellent points raised here.

One of the trends I've been observed is a decline in all the cobot hype.  Companies like UR did a fantastic job marketing their products in the last decade, but it didn't really change the game in industrial automation.  While it may have inspired people to think about deploying robots differently, they took more of an evolutionary change.  They added more vision, simulation or more intelligent safety systems (e.g., zoning, pausing).  Most robots are still behind guarding though.  They're optimized for speed and reliability over collaboration.  Cobots didn't really make the tried-and-true practices of industrial robots go away.  They just evolved slightly with complementary technology.

Another trend is that normal industrial robots could be augmented with more advanced safety systems.  For example, Veobot's Free Move product allows one to interlock vision with an industrial robot's safety bus.

Fanuc, ABB, and Kuka dominate most material handling, painting/welding, and inspection applications.  They have strong ecosystems with talent available around the world.  They also have excellent secondary / refurbished markets.  Industrial robot technology, believe it or not, actually evolves very slowly.  In most projects, the latest functionality may not be necessary.  There are now robots that are about 10-15 years old with mainstream ethernet fieldbus support, integrated safety, and simulation.  Pairing this with a modern PLC with integrated safety+motion provides a lot of flexibility and value.  Anything with a modern Fanuc R-30 controller with the right connectivity options is hard to beat.  It's not flashy and it's a bit quirky at first, but it just works.  

Another thing to consider is making sure robots are licensed with sufficient position registers.  This helps more intelligently integrate routines and recovery programs into the overall automation of a cell.  It makes it easier on operators, technicians, etc.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Regarding inspection, @jpmoniz nailed it.  Don't just jump into inspection applications with robots.  

Some machine builders and SIs try to get into the vision/gaging world and fail miserably.  Engineering a reliable and repeatable inspection process is significantly more challenging than engineering a material handling process.  Most overlook that robots aren't actually precise and repeatable enough for many inspection applications.  Often, the real "magic" happens in end-of-arm-tooling and fixture design.  People try to take shortcuts here to reduce cost, but it usually ends up coming back to haunt them.  If the mechanical process is not stable, then the inspection process will not be stable.  Robots exacerbate this problem.

The most advanced non-contact surface condition and metrology stuff with robotics I've seen is with SmartRay and MVTec Halcon.

More important than market size is finding customers with sufficient technological maturity and reasonable expectations.  There are a lot of manufacturers that build lazy business cases for automating inspection on the basis of solely reducing labor costs.  What they fail to realize is that they can't completely outsource the problem.  They have to develop some internal capability and take some ownership of the solution.  Those that are successful don't look for a 12 month payback on eliminating a labor-intensive inspection process.  Instead, they look for how to adopt the technology broadly throughout their operations and collaborate with their vendors.  Once they understand this, they will have a better understanding of where the technology works and delivers value.  In other words, it's not a simple 1:1 replacement of labor with capital.  Anyone who tries to outsource strategy and know-how about their process in a turn-key solution is asking for trouble.

Finally, don't believe everything the hardware vendors say.  Most aren't "true" application engineers.  They're sales people that can run demos.
